question.p: In a large statistics class, the correlation between midterm scores and final scores is found to be nearly 0.7, every term. The scatter diagrams are football-shaped. Predict the percentile rank on the final for a student whose percentile rank on the midterm is:

A basketball coach conducts an interesting experiment to help his players hit three pointers. On Monday, he has each player on his team take ten shots from right behind the three point line, in the middle of the court. If the player makes three or fewer of his shots, then the coach makes him run ten laps around the court. In the player makes seven or more shots, then the coach high-fives him and buys him a Gatorade. Finally, if the player makes between four and six shots, then the coach just tells him "good job".

On Tuesday, he has each player take ten shots again from the same location. The coach observes that the players he made run laps on Monday tended to make more shots on Tuesday, the players he rewarded with a Gatorade tended to make fewer shots on Tuesday, and the players to whom he said "good job" made the same number of shots. To verify this hypothesis, the coach repeats this experiment five times, and finds that the same conclusions hold. The coach concludes that praise doesn't work on basketball players, and decides that in his practices when players miss too many shots he will just make them run laps.
Do you agree with the coach's conclusions?

solution.p: Not necessarily. It's very possible that the coach is just observing regression to the mean. We would expect the players who did poorly on Monday to improve on Tuesday, and the people who played well to do worse, regardless of the treatment.
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.

ul.li: 2 points for getting the conclusion right
2 points for recognizing "regression to the mean" or "regression effect". The student need not use these terms explicitly if they understand the idea.
2 points for using the regression effect to explain both why the players who were punished did better and why the players who were rewarded did worse.

It is a common misconception that if a player did below average on Monday, he'll do above average on Tuesday. In fact, his average on Tuesday would be no different from on any other days, it's just that he'll tend to do better than on Monday because Monday was below average. Take off 2 points if the student makes this mistake.
Feel free to give partial credit or to use your good judgement if you think the case merits it

question.name: Sports Illustrated Jinx
question.p: Athletes who appear on the cover of Sports Illustrated magazine will subsequently perform worse. Is this a jinx?

Let's imagine that we have some way of comparing athletes' performances across sports. Only the best athletes get their photos on the cover of SI, so let's suppose that such athletes are at the 95th percentile among all athletes that week. Also, suppose the correlation of ``performance'' from one week to the next is $0.6$.

What percentage of the athletes on the cover of SI one week (i.e., at the 95th percentile) would you naturally expect to do worse the next (i.e., below the 95th percentile of all players)? Show your work.

solution.p: Work in standard units. Athletes at the 95th percentile this week have a $z$-score of 1.65. Since the correlation is 0.6, we would expect them to be at a $z$-score of $0.6 \times 1.65 = 0.99$ next week. This is the average performance next week among players in the 95th percentile this week.

We are interested in the percentage of players who will do better than $1.65$ next week. To calculate this, we also need to know the SD of performances next week among players in the 95th percentile this week. This is given by: \[ \text{new SD} = \sqrt{1-0.6^2}\times 1 = 0.8 \] Therefore, a performance of 1.65 represents a z-score of $z = \frac{1.65 - 0.99}{0.8} = 0.825$ next week. Looking at the normal table, we would expect about 79% of athletes to perform below this level.
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.

ul.li: 2 points for determining that the predicted performance next week among people in the 95th percentile this week is 0.99 SD's above the mean.
2 points for determining that the "new SD" (the SD of values in the vertical strip) is 0.8 SD's.
2 points for calculating that 79% of athletes in the vertical strip will perform below the 95th percentile next week.

question.p:
Suppose the heights of sons and fathers has a correlation of 0.6, and both sons and fathers have an average height of 68 inches.
If the average height of sons of 74-inch fathers is 72 inches, does this mean that the average height of fathers of 72-inch sons is 74 inches? Explain.
If the average height of sons of 68-inch fathers is 68 inches, does this mean that the average height of fathers of 68-inch sons is 68 inches? Explain.

solution.p: No, the average height of fathers of 72-inch sons should not be 74 inches. This is due to the difference between the regression line fitting heights of sons to heights of fathers, and the regression line fitting heights of fathers to heights of sons. In both cases, we expect regression to the mean, and since 72 inches is above the mean for sons, the average height of fathers of 72-inch sons should be less than 72 (but greater than 68). If the question were about 68-inch fathers whose sons average 68 inches, then the answer would be yes, since both heights are already at the mean, so both regression lines intersect that point.
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.

ul.li: 4 points for concluding "no" in part (a) and explaining that there is a difference between regressing y on x and regressing x on y, or applying regression to the mean to answer the question.
2 points for concluding "yes" in part (b) and explaining that there is no regression when x and y are already at the mean (or equivalent).
Feel free to give partial credit or to use your good judgement if you think the case merits it
